items.title: More than 50 dump truck loads of dirt were removed from his yard. Now, he has to put them back
Tumbler Ridge, B.C., mayor concerned about ambulance staffing levels
items.summary_auto: New data is raising concerns about ambulance staffing levels in Tumbler Ridge, B.C., months after hours were cut at the local emergency department.

items.title: 3 journalists killed in Israeli airstrike on car in central Gaza, health officials say
items.summary_auto: Israeli fire killed 11 Palestinians, including two boys and three journalists, in Gaza on Wednesday, local medics said, and the Israeli military said it had "eliminated" a Palestinian militant who posed a threat to soldiers.

items.title: Canada's Mboko advances to 3rd round at Australian Open
items.summary_auto: Victoria Mboko of Toronto punched her ticket to the third round of women's singles at the Australian Open on Wednesday in Melbourne with a 6-4, 6-3 win over American Caty McNally.

items.title: Fire in Montreal forces closure of Jacques-Cartier Bridge
items.summary_auto: A fire that started in an abandoned building on De Lorimier Avenue in Montreal has forced the closure of the Jacques-Cartier Bridge ahead of the Wednesday morning rush hour.

items.title: Struggle and hope: the challenge of saving the coastal dialect of Inuvialuktun
items.summary_auto: Elders in Paulatuk, N.W.T., say more can be done to save their coastal dialect of Inuvialuktun. A language program that's gained momentum recently in Tuktoyaktuk sheds light on a successful strategy — and a reason to hope Sallirmiutun won't disappear.

items.title: New data ranks Halifax 3rd worst in Canada for traffic congestion
items.summary_auto: The latest traffic index from geolocation company TomTom shows Halifax traffic congestion remains among the worst in Canada, with the city ranking 147th in the world.

items.title: Man who assassinated former Japanese PM Shinzo Abe gets life in prison
items.summary_auto: A Japanese court sentenced a man who admitted assassinating former Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe to life imprisonment on Wednesday.

items.title: What the trial for an Ontario couple has heard so far from woman co-accused of killing boy, torturing brother
items.summary_auto: The trial for a couple who'd been trying to adopt two brothers before one was found dead in their Burlington, Ont., home four years ago is set to end proceedings on Friday. Following her wife's testimony, Becky Hamber answered questions from lawyers, including about how the two treated the children. Here's what we've heard from Hamber so far in Milton Superior Court.

items.title: Not ‘luxury’ enough? Toronto's Yorkdale mall owners fight to keep Fairweather out
items.summary_auto: Oxford Properties is fighting in court to stop Fairweather from taking over the large space that was once occupied by Hudson’s Bay, arguing its stores feel "downmarket" and could damage the mall’s image.

items.title: The rulebook overhaul that could help Canada’s only F1 driver outrun his billionaire dad’s shadow
items.summary_auto: Canada’s lone Formula One driver has spent his career plagued by the claim that he hasn’t earned his spot in F1. But all eyes are on 2026 and the overhaul in F1’s technical regulations that could finally change everything.

items.title: Public consultations into high-speed rail begin today. Your questions answered
items.summary_auto: Public consultations on the proposed high-speed rail line begin Wednesday in Ottawa and Montreal.

items.title: Dalhousie University strips Buffy Sainte-Marie of honorary degree
items.summary_auto: Dalhousie University has revoked Buffy Sainte-Marie's honorary degree after her claims to Indigenous identity were the subject of a 2023 CBC News investigation, and a formal request from a medical student who raised concerns about the harms in keeping the honour.

items.title: Indigenous leaders say Legault's resignation an opportunity for long-awaited changes
items.summary_auto: Some are hoping Premier François Legault's successor will revive some of the commitments his government previously made, like recognizing UNDRIP and concluding a major treaty, which never came to fruition.

items.title: The violence began behind closed doors. It ended in Canada’s worst mass shooting
items.summary_auto: The partner of Canada's worst mass shooter survived years of abuse before he would go on a rampage that killed 22 people across rural Nova Scotia. Her experiences are detailed in a book released Tuesday and speak to a wider truth, she says: that the violence that begins behind closed doors can spill into society.

items.title: Reports of intimate partner violence in Quebec triple over last decade
items.summary_auto: Quebec provincial police are reporting a significant increase in intimate partner violence cases, though they say it does not necessarily mean more violence is occurring.

items.title: The world wonders what — if anything — can restrain Trump on Greenland
items.summary_auto: As U.S. President Donald Trump’s insistence on controlling Greenland becomes even more vehement despite polls showing most Americans don't support it, there’s a growing sense of urgency around the globe to figure out if there is anything that could change his mind.

items.title: Greenlanders looking for Canadian support amid U.S. threats, Governor General says
items.summary_auto: The people of Greenland are looking to Canada for support as they continue to face threats of annexation from the U.S., says Gov. Gen. Mary Simon. Simon, a former ambassador to Denmark and Canada’s first ambassador for Circumpolar Affairs, says she has spoken with Greenlanders who feel “uneasy” about U.S. President Donald Trump’s stated desire to make their territory part of the U.S.

items.title: Witnesses describe Myles Gray’s behaviour prior to his death at Vancouver police conduct hearing
items.summary_auto: Tuesday’s witnesses included those who saw Myles Gray acting unusually before he made his way into a Joffre Avenue yard in Burnaby, near the Vancouver border.

items.title: #TheMoment scientists got a look inside a glacier
items.summary_auto: Martin Froger Silva, a videographer for the Center for Oldest Ice Exploration, tells The National about the moment he filmed the inside of a glacier in Antarctica that’s millions of years old.

items.title: Minister says Alberta emergency room deaths and poor outcomes are exceptions to the norm
items.summary_auto: As Alberta doctors raise red flags about seeing what they say are delays in emergency room care, the province’s hospitals minister says he doesn’t think cases that the doctors have recently highlighted reflect the health system broadly.

items.title: Ontario-born Rachel McAdams gets a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame
items.summary_auto: Canadian actress Rachel McAdams became the latest star to land a spot onto the Hollywood Walk of Fame on Tuesday.

items.title: Manitoba respiratory therapists 'in crisis mode' amid staffing shortage, union says
items.summary_auto: A provincewide shortage of respiratory therapists threatens to get worse with an exodus of retirees anticipated in the coming years and an inadequate number of Manitoba-based respiratory therapy graduates "in the pipeline," warns a union that represents thousands of allied health-care workers.

items.title: Vancouver palliative care doctor tells court she resigned rather than authorize MAID transfers
items.summary_auto: A Vancouver palliative care doctor, who says she chose to resign rather than authorize patient transfers for the purpose of medical assistance in dying (MAID), took the stand in the B.C. Supreme Court case that will determine the constitutionality of faith-based, publicly funded health-care facilities prohibiting MAID in their buildings.

items.title: Beckham vs. Beckham: Brooklyn Peltz Beckham's rant against parents David, Victoria explained
items.summary_auto: Brooklyn Peltz Beckham held nothing back in a seething social media rant calling out his superstar parents — soccer legend Sir David Beckham and ex-Spice Girl Lady Victoria Beckham.

items.title: Driver killed in Spain's 2nd deadly train accident in days
items.summary_auto: Commuter rail service in Spain's northeastern Catalonia region was suspended Wednesday after a Barcelona commuter train crashed the night before, Spanish authorities said.

items.title: Is Donald Trump auctioning off Gaza’s future?
items.summary_auto: Andrew Chang explains what $1 billion US buys members on Trump's new Board of Peace. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre will run in a different riding next federal election: party
items.summary_auto: The party confirmed Damien Kurek — who held the seat previously — would run in the Battle River-Crowfoot riding in the next election. Kurek gave up his seat last year so Poilievre could run in that electoral district.

items.title: Testimony wraps in Texas officer's trial over response to 2022 Uvalde school shooting
items.summary_auto: Witness testimony ended Tuesday in the trial of a former Uvalde, Texas, school police officer accused of failing in his duty to stop a gunman in the critical first minutes of the 2022 Robb Elementary School attack, setting up the case to go to the jury.

items.title: Did Carney just signal a massive shift in Canada's foreign policy direction?
U.S. says it has seized 7th Venezuela-linked oil tanker
items.summary_auto: U.S. military forces boarded and took control of a seventh oil tanker connected with Venezuela on Tuesday as the Trump administration continues its efforts to take control of the oil in the South American country.

items.title: Veronika the cow has a scratching broom, and she knows how to use it
items.summary_auto: Veronika the brown cow's dexterous and graceful tool use upends long-held assumptions about the intelligence of cows, say scientists.

items.title: Indigenous physician Dr. Barry Lavallee remembered as 'fearless advocate': Keewatinohk Inniniw Minoayawin
items.summary_auto: Dr. Barry Lavallee, a prominent Indigenous physician whose work focused on improving health care for First Nations and Métis people in Manitoba, has died, Keewatinohk Inniniw Minoayawin said Tuesday.

items.title: Timelapse video shows northern lights glowing in Yukon
items.summary_auto: The northern lights, also known as the aurora borealis, put on a show in parts of Canada, the U.S. and Europe overnight Monday into Tuesday, with the vivid display seen much farther south than usual amid intense geomagnetic and solar radiation storms. Video that has been verified by Reuters shows shimmering green and pink hues in the sky over the Yukon hamlet of Mount Lorne.

items.title: Ottawa, provinces ask Supreme Court to uphold law on random traffic stops
items.summary_auto: The country's top court spent a second morning hearing arguments about whether it's constitutional for police to make traffic stops without reasonable suspicion the driver has committed an offence.

items.title: Art Gallery of Hamilton to expand, incorporate housing in ‘first-of-its-kind in Canada’ renovation
items.summary_auto: The Art Gallery of Hamilton has announced a planned renovation to grow its space by 20 per cent and incorporate affordable housing for artists.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Dust storm turns Libya a surreal orange
items.summary_auto: A heavy dust storm swept across Libya on Tuesday, reducing visibility, forcing the temporary suspension of flights at two airports and shrouding cities there with a thick orange haze.

items.title: Europe’s 'appeasement' strategy with Trump has failed. So what comes next?
items.summary_auto: On Tuesday, U.S. President Donald Trump accused British Prime Minister Keir Starmer of an act of “great stupidity” for returning an island to Mauritius that houses an important military base. The episode shows how fast Trump can turn on international partners, and raises questions about Europe’s strategy for dealing with the volatile U.S. president.

items.title: Family warns ending inquests for jail deaths 'turns a person into a number'
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s Ministry of the Solicitor General is reviewing feedback on a possible amendment to its Coroners Act that may replace mandatory inquests into jail deaths with coroner-led annual reviews. Chris Bolt, who recently watched the inquest into the death of his sister Amanda, says the change will cause more harm than good.

items.title: B.C. RCMP says it's 'actively hunting' extortionists, urges public not to take matters into their own hands
items.summary_auto: Police are probing the 35th case of suspected extortion in Surrey, B.C., this year alone — but B.C. RCMP assistant commissioner says it does not constitute a crisis.
